Description: This curve represents the confidence level assigned by an interpreter to a lithofacies classification. It is typically scored on a scale (e.g., 1 for high confidence, 3 for low confidence) and can be used to weigh or filter data during analysis.
This curve provides a machine-predicted or interpreted lithofacies class label for a given depth. It is used in machine learning competitions for predicting lithology based on well log data.

The Caliper log measures the diameter of the borehole. It is used to detect variations in the borehole size, such as washouts or enlargements, which can indicate different lithologies or borehole conditions.

The Bit Size (BS) log records the diameter of the drill bit used. It is essential for understanding borehole conditions and can be compared with caliper logs to identify wellbore enlargements or washouts.
The Differential Caliper (DCAL) log measures the distance between the tool sensor and the borehole wall, providing a sensitive indicator of borehole conditions and quality of other log measurements.

Mud weight, or mud density, is a critical drilling fluid property that controls formation pressure and contributes to wellbore stability. It is measured in units like pounds per gallon (PPG) or grams per milliliter (g/ml).

The Rate of Penetration (ROP) measures how quickly the drill bit is advancing through rock formations, typically in meters per hour (m/h) or feet per hour. It provides insights into drilling efficiency, formation hardness, and can aid in lithology identification.

Deep Resistivity (RDEP) logs measure the electrical resistivity of the formation at a greater depth of investigation. This deep reading helps in identifying hydrocarbon-bearing zones and calculating water saturation.

Shallow Resistivity (RSHA) logs measure the electrical resistivity of the formation closer to the borehole wall, in the flushed zone. This is often referred to as a micro-resistivity log and is influenced by borehole fluids.

Medium Resistivity (RMED) logs provide an intermediate depth of investigation between shallow and deep resistivity logs. This measurement helps in a more comprehensive analysis of formation fluids and lithology.

The Spontaneous Potential (SP) log measures natural electrical potentials in the borehole. It is used to identify permeable rock layers and distinguish them from impermeable layers like shale, and can also help determine formation water resistivity.
The Compressional Travel Time (DTC) log measures the time it takes for a compressional sound wave to travel through a formation. It is used to determine porosity, elastic properties, and lithology.

Neutron Porosity (NPHI) logs measure the hydrogen content in a formation, which is then converted to an apparent porosity value. It is primarily used to identify potential hydrocarbon zones and calculate porosity.

The Gamma Ray (GR) log measures the natural radioactivity of formations, which is primarily emitted by shales and clays. It is used to distinguish between shales and non-shales, aiding in lithology identification.

The Bulk Density (RHOB) log measures the overall density of the formation, including solids and fluids. It is used to calculate porosity and identify lithology, with higher densities often indicating tighter formations.

The Density Correction (DRHO) log indicates the magnitude of correction applied to density measurements, often related to borehole conditions. Values outside a certain range can suggest unreliable density data.
